data.title: 250 by 2050: Cultivating more million-dollar companies in Saskatchewan
data.description:
Regina, Saskatchewan, Feb. 04, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) — Supporting 250 Saskatchewan companies with annual recurring revenues (ARR) of one million dollars by 2050. That is Cultivator powered by Conexus’ new ambitious target.  

Since 2019, 15 companies in the business incubator’s programming have achieved this revenue milestone. Cultivator is now setting its sights on a “35 by 2030” and a “250 by 2050” target.  

“We know that tech companies and the jobs they create are more likely to exist for the long haul once they reach this revenue target,” says Cultivator Director Laura Mock. “It’s a critical benchmark. One million in ARR also tends to be the magic number for when a company is ready for Series A investment.” 

“This new target fastens together Cultivator’s global agtech and Saskatchewan tech incubation portfolios into a singular focus: cultivating companies with million-dollar recurring revenues.”  

The business incubator made the announcement at Cultivator Community Night on Saturday, Feb. 1, 2025. The celebration also featured a founder panel and an announcement of the 24-Hour Startup winners. 24-Hour Startup is a fast-paced event Cultivator hosts where teams formed just the day before build a minimum viable product in 24 hours.  

The credit union connection 

Cultivator powered by Conexus prides itself on being the first credit-union led business incubator in Canada. 

“900 Conexus employees work tirelessly every day with a singular purpose – championing this province and its people,” explains Conexus CEO Celina Philpot. “Cultivator powered by Conexus’ audacious 250 by 2050 goal demonstrates an unwavering commitment to a thriving Saskatchewan.” 

“Your credit union is working alongside you to grow the economic vitality of our province.” 

For more information and to arrange interviews, please contact: 

Michael Chmielewski 

Media Relations Specialist | Conexus Credit Union 

media@conexus.ca | 306-751-8201

About Cultivator powered by Conexus 

Cultivator powered by Conexus is Canada’s first credit union led tech incubator, helping local startups start, grow, and scale their companies right here in Saskatchewan. We believe the prairies are home to some of the world’s most resilient founders. Since launching in 2019, Cultivator has incubated and provided resources, mentorship, and support to over 170 startups. Visit Cultivator.ca for more information. 

About Conexus Credit Union 

We’re a forward-thinking, Saskatchewan-based credit union committed to our members and their financial well-being. We’re a member-owned cooperative with more than 80 years of serving members and giving back to our community. Conexus’ purpose is to champion every member’s success for a thriving Saskatchewan. Visit Conexus.ca for more information.

Attachment

  • Photo of Cultivator Director Laura Mock

Michael Chmielewski

Conexus Credit Union

306-751-8201

media@conexus.ca

data.title: Bernstein Adjusts Price Target on Tyson Foods to $75 From $72, Maintains Outperform Rating
data.description: Tyson Foods has an average rating of hold and mean price target of $64.55, according to analysts polled by FactSet.

data.title: ATI's Q4 Adjusted Earnings, Sales Increase; Q1, 2025 Outlook Issued
data.description:
ATI reported Q4 adjusted earnings Tuesday of $0.79 per diluted share, up from $0.64 a year earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet expected $0.61.

Sales for the quarter ended Dec. 29 were $1.17 billion, compared with $1.06 billion a year earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet expected $1.09 billion.

The specialty materials company said it expects Q1 adjusted EPS of $0.55 to $0.61. Analysts polled by FactSet expect $0.59.

ATI said it expects 2025 adjusted EPS of $2.80 to $3. Analysts polled by FactSet expect $2.92.

ATI shares were up 5% in recent premarket activity Tuesday.

data.title: Earnings Flash (IESC) IES Holdings Reports Fiscal Q1 Adjusted EPS $2.64
Serbia's debt-to-GDP ratio narrows to 47.4% at end-2024 - table
data.description:
BELGRADE (Serbia), February 4 (SeeNews) - Serbia's public debt-to-GDP ratio narrowed at the end of December 2024 to 47.4% of the gross domestic product (GDP) projected for the year, from 48% of GDP at the end of 2023, the finance ministry said on Tuesday.

In absolute numbers, Serbia's public debt rose to 38.874 billion euro ($40.128 billion) at the end of 2024 from 36.153 billion euro at the end of the prior year, the finance ministry said in a data release.

On a monthly comparison basis, however, the public debt-to-GDP ratio widened in December from 46.8% of GDP at the end of November, when Serbia's public debt volume stood at 38.393 billion euro.

Following is the country's public debt structure, in billions of euro, as given by the finance ministry:

end-Dec '24end-Nov '24end-Dec '23
TOTAL PUBLIC DEBT38.87438.39336.153
Direct liabilities37.04336.57434.337
- Internal debt10.57110.38710.272
- External debt26.47126.18724.065
Indirect liabilities1.8321.8191.816
-Internal debt0.4610.4790.519
-External debt1.3711.3401.297

($ = 0.969 euro)

data.title: Archer-Daniels-Midland's Q4 Adjusted Earnings, Revenue Fall; 2025 Non-GAAP EPS Guidance Issued
data.description:
Archer-Daniels-Midland reported Q4 adjusted earnings Tuesday of $1.14 per diluted share, down from $1.36 a year earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet expected $1.14.

Revenue for the quarter ended Dec. 31 was $21.50 billion, compared with $22.98 billion a year earlier.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected $22.77 billion.

The company said it expects 2025 adjusted earnings of $4 to $4.75 per share.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expect $4.71.
